name: Black vs 1. e4 (Playing e5)
description: A solid 1...e5 repertoire. Against the Italian (Bc4), we play the Two Knights with the correct Polerio Defense. Against the Spanish (Bb5), we play the solid Morphy Defense. Deep coverage of critical lines.

tree.explanation: White plays the King's Pawn Opening.

children.explanation: We mirror White's central control! This is the classical response, leading to open games with piece activity.
White attacks our e5 pawn. We must defend.
We develop and defend e5. The most natural and best move.
The Italian Game. White's bishop targets our weak f7 pawn (only defended by our king).
The Two Knights Defense! We counterattack e4 instead of passively defending with Bc5. More aggressive and leads to exciting play.
The Knight Attack! White immediately threatens Nxf7, forking queen and rook. Scary but we know the defense!
THE ONLY MOVE! We block the bishop's view of f7. Don't panic - just remember d5! Any other move loses.
White captures. Now the critical moment - DO NOT take back on d5!
THE POLERIO DEFENSE! Attack the bishop instead of recapturing. 5...Nxd5?? loses to the Fried Liver (6.Nxf7!). This is the key move to remember!
White saves the bishop with check. The main line.
We block and attack the d5 pawn. Sharp play ahead but we're fine.
White captures.
We recapture. We're technically down a pawn but have huge activity and attacking chances. Theory says this is equal.
The most common retreat. White keeps the piece safe.
We kick the annoying knight. It has no good squares.
The knight retreats home.
We gain space and restrict White's knight. Now we have a strong center.
The knight finds an outpost.
We develop with tempo, attacking the knight. Our pieces are very active.
White tries to challenge our center.
We capture en passant. Black has excellent compensation - active pieces, open lines, and attacking chances against White's king.
Alternative - the knight goes to the center.
We develop actively, pressuring the knight.
White castles.
We castle too. Dynamic position where Black has excellent piece play for the pawn.
An awkward retreat to the rim.
We develop actively. The knight on h3 is misplaced.
Alternative retreat - the bishop is more active here.
Our knight occupies a powerful central square.
The knight retreats.
We develop. Black has excellent compensation with the powerful knight on d5.
White threatens mate on f7!
Check! We block the f7 threat and force White's king to move or block.
White loses castling rights.
Now we kick the knight. Black is doing great - White can't castle!
White tries to hold the extra pawn quietly.
We kick the knight first.
The knight retreats.
We gain space and attack the knight. Excellent compensation.
White captures.
We win the bishop! Material is now equal with a great position.
White tries to defend.
We grab the bishop. Black is better.
A desperate sacrifice. Don't be scared!
We step to e7, not taking the bishop! This keeps our king safe and we'll win the piece back.
White retreats.
Kick the knight. Black is clearly better.
THE FRIED LIVER TRAP! This natural recapture LOSES. White plays 6. Nxf7! and your king gets dragged into the open. Never play this!
The Fried Liver Attack! White sacrifices the knight to expose our king. We're in huge trouble.
We must take.
Check! White attacks our knight too. We're lost.
The Giuoco Pianissimo approach. White avoids sharp play.
We develop our bishop actively.
White prepares d4.
Solid. We reinforce e5.
White castles.
We castle. Solid, equal game.
White develops the knight to d2, heading for f1-g3.
We prepare ...Ba7 to keep the bishop safe and ...b5 for queenside play.
White repositions the bishop.
Our bishop retreats to a safe diagonal. It still eyes f2 from here.
The knight maneuver begins.
We develop and offer to trade White's strong bishop.
White pins our knight.
We ask the bishop what it wants to do.
White maintains the pin.
We kick the bishop! This weakens our kingside slightly but gains the bishop pair.
The bishop retreats.
We attack the bishop! After Bxe5 dxe5, we have the bishop pair and a strong center.
Alternative - preparing ...Ba7 immediately.
White castles.
Safe bishop, still aiming at f2.
White castles immediately.
We solidify. Same structure will arise.
Prophylaxis! We prevent Ng5 and Bg5 forever. Very practical approach.
White continues normally.
Now we develop. Transposing back to normal lines.
The Italian Four Knights.
We can safely grab the pawn! If Nxe4, d5 wins the piece back with a great position.
White recaptures.
Fork! We attack the knight and bishop. Winning the piece back with a great center.
The Italian Gambit / Scotch Gambit hybrid.
We capture, opening the position.
White kicks our knight.
We counterattack the bishop! If exf6, dxc4 and we're a pawn up.
The Giuoco Piano. More solid than the Two Knights but less dynamic. Good alternative.
White prepares d4.
We develop and attack e4.
White strikes in the center.
We capture.
White recaptures.
Check! This is the main theoretical line.
White blocks.
We trade. Simple chess with equal chances.
Grabbing a pawn! Sharp play but theory says it's fine for Black.
White develops with a block.
We grab the pawn. Complex play ahead.
The quiet approach.
Solid setup. Same type of game as our Two Knights lines.
The Ruy Lopez (Spanish Game). The most respected and deeply analyzed opening. White pins our knight indirectly pressuring e5.
The Morphy Defense! We ask the bishop to declare its intentions. By far the most popular response.
White maintains the pin. The bishop retreats but stays active.
We develop and attack e4. The most common and best move.
White castles, getting the king to safety.
The Closed Defense. We prepare to castle. This is the main line for solid play.
White reinforces e4 and opens the possibility of d4.
We chase the bishop and prepare ...Bb7 for the fianchetto.
The bishop retreats to a safe diagonal.
We reinforce e5 and complete our solid setup.
White prepares d4.
We castle. A typical Ruy Lopez middlegame with rich strategic play ahead.
Preventing ...Bg4 pin.
The Chigorin Variation! We attack the dangerous bishop.
White saves the bishop.
We challenge White's center. A complex middlegame lies ahead with chances for both sides.
The Breyer Variation! The knight retreats to reroute to d7. Highly respected at top levels.
White seizes space.
The knight completes its journey. Solid structure.
White plays d4 immediately.
We pin the knight! This is why White usually plays h3 first.
We can castle immediately too. Transposes to similar positions.
The Open Spanish! We grab the pawn. Sharp tactical play ahead.
White strikes in the center.
We must chase the bishop before it captures on c6.
The bishop retreats.
We secure our knight on e4 and claim central space.
White captures.
We develop. Complex positions with chances for both sides. Black has active piece play.
Chasing the bishop immediately is also played.
White retreats.
The Archangel Variation. Active and interesting.
Transposes back to the main Closed Defense.
A quiet approach, avoiding the main lines.
We develop normally.
White castles.
We gain space and chase the bishop.
The Exchange Variation. White takes immediately, damaging our pawns but giving us the bishop pair.
We recapture toward the center! Our doubled pawns are ugly but we have the bishop pair and open lines.
White grabs the pawn.
We attack the knight AND e4! We win the pawn back immediately.
The knight retreats.
We recover the pawn with check. Equal game with the bishop pair as compensation for the doubled pawns.
Quiet development.
We develop actively. The bishop pair is valuable in these open positions.
The Berlin Defense. Very solid, often leading to drawish endgames. Popular at top levels but less fun for beginners.
White castles.
We grab the pawn. The famous Berlin endgame can arise after 5.d4 Nd6 6.Bxc6 dxc6 7.dxe5 Nf5 8.Qxd8+ Kxd8.
White strikes in the center.
Our knight retreats to attack the bishop.
The Scotch Game. White immediately opens the center.
We capture.
White recaptures.
We develop and attack e4.
White trades.
We recapture toward the center. Open position with equal chances.
White kicks our knight.
We pin the pawn! After Qe2 Nd5, we have a fine game.
White develops.
We develop actively, pressuring the knight.
We develop actively, attacking the knight.
White defends the knight.
We attack the knight from another angle and threaten ...Qxf2#!
White defends f2 indirectly.
We develop. Equal position with active play for both sides.
The Scotch Gambit. White gambits the pawn for rapid development.
We develop and attack e4.
White kicks our knight.
We counterattack! The best response.
The Three Knights Game. Less common but solid.
We develop naturally. Now it's the Four Knights.
The Spanish Four Knights.
We mirror! Symmetrical position but Black is fine.
The Center Game. White opens immediately but has to bring the queen out early.
We capture.
White's queen is in the center early - we can attack it!
We develop with tempo! The queen must move again.
The queen retreats.
We develop. Black has easy equality - White wasted time with the queen.
The Danish Gambit! White sacrifices pawns for rapid development.
We take! We should accept gambits and defend carefully.
White gets rapid development.
We develop. White has compensation but we're a pawn up with correct play.
The Bishop's Opening. White develops but doesn't immediately pressure e5.
We develop and attack e4!
White defends.
Simple development. Equal game.
The Vienna Game. White prepares f4.
We develop and attack e4.
The Vienna Gambit!
We strike in the center! The best response.
White takes.
We grab the pawn. Complex play but Black is fine.
